verses.text: What then shall we say that Abraham, our forefather according to the flesh, has found?
verses.comment: Paul begins with Abraham as the example of justification, highlighting the shared ancestry and the importance of Abraham's role. The question underlines a search for understanding regarding how righteousness is received.

verses.text: For if Abraham was justified by works, he has reason to boast—but not before God.
verses.comment: Paul clarifies it is not human works that justify us before God. This shows that even Abraham, the great patriarch, cannot claim merit before God based solely on deeds.

verses.text: For what does the Scripture say? 'Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him as righteousness.'
verses.comment: Paul quotes Genesis 15:6 to show faith as the foundation for righteousness. This underscores the necessity of faith, but also points to the scriptural pattern of grace preceding works.

verses.text: Now to the one who works, his wage is not credited as a gift but as something owed.
verses.comment: Here Paul distinguishes between wages (earned by work) and a gift (received by grace). Righteousness is described as a divine gift, not something owed.

verses.text: But to the one who does not work but trusts in Him who justifies the ungodly, his faith is credited as righteousness.
verses.comment: Faith alone unites the believer to God's grace, emphasizing God's initiative in justification. Yet nothing here excludes the role of grace changing the heart for future works.

verses.text: Just as David also speaks of the blessing on the man to whom God credits righteousness apart from works:
verses.comment: David’s psalm is cited as a further Old Testament witness that the forgiveness and justification of God is primary, coming before and apart from our works.

verses.text: "Blessed are those whose lawless deeds are forgiven, and whose sins are covered;
verses.comment: The forgiveness of sins is a deep blessing. The metaphor of covering sin alludes to God’s atonement and anticipates the sacramental means by which grace would be ministered.

verses.text: blessed is the man against whom the Lord will not count his sin."
verses.comment: This emphasizes the assurance of being in God's favor when forgiven. Paul’s use of David links the Psalms to the New Testament revelation of God’s mercy.

verses.text: Is this blessing only for the circumcised, or also for the uncircumcised? For we say that faith was credited to Abraham as righteousness.
verses.comment: Paul raises the question of universality—righteousness by faith is available to both Jew and Gentile. This displays the faith as preceding signs or ritual.

verses.text: How then was it credited? Was it after he had been circumcised, or before? It was not after, but before he was circumcised.
verses.comment: Paul points out that Abraham was justified by faith before the command of circumcision, emphasizing faith and obedience flowing from grace.

verses.text: He received the sign of circumcision as a seal of the righteousness that he had by faith while he was still uncircumcised. So he is the father of all who believe without being circumcised, so that righteousness would be credited to them as well,
verses.comment: Rites and sacraments are shown as outward signs that seal an already-existing internal reality of grace and faith, reflecting a pattern continued in New Testament practices.

verses.text: and also the father of the circumcised who not only are circumcised but who also walk in the steps of the faith that our father Abraham had before he was circumcised.
verses.comment: Abraham’s paternity is both natural and spiritual for those who follow his faith, pointing to the importance of faith preceding external works, yet not excluding their importance.

verses.text: For the promise to Abraham or to his descendants that he would inherit the world was not through the law, but through the righteousness of faith.
verses.comment: The inheritance is traced to a promise grounded in faith, not law, highlighting God's covenantal faithfulness. Christ fulfills this as the true descendant.

verses.text: For if those who are of the law are heirs, faith is made empty and the promise is canceled;
verses.comment: If inheritance depended solely on the law, the purpose and effect of faith would be void. This underlines the need for faith in receiving God's promises.

verses.text: for the law produces wrath, but where there is no law, neither is there transgression.
verses.comment: The law makes us aware of sin but cannot save us. This points to the necessity of grace poured out through faith.

verses.text: For this reason, it depends on faith, so that it may be by grace—that the promise may be guaranteed to all the descendants, not only to those who are of the law but also to those who share the faith of Abraham, who is the father of us all.
verses.comment: The certainty of the promise rests on grace accessed by faith. This opens the blessing to all nations, uniting believers in one spiritual lineage.

verses.text: As it is written: 'I have made you the father of many nations.' He is our father in the presence of God, in whom he believed—the God who gives life to the dead and calls into being things that do not exist.
verses.comment: Paul draws from Genesis, noting that God’s creative power and Abraham’s faith in resurrection prefigure Christ’s own resurrection and the promise to all nations.

verses.text: In hope against hope, he believed, so that he might become the father of many nations, according to what was spoken: 'So shall your offspring be.'
verses.comment: Abraham’s radical hope and trust is highlighted as the model of faith. His story also anticipates God’s faithfulness through miraculous means, fulfilled fully in Christ.

verses.text: He did not weaken in faith when he considered his own body, which was already as good as dead—since he was about a hundred years old—or when he considered the barrenness of Sarah’s womb.
verses.comment: Despite natural limitations, Abraham’s trust in God’s promise did not waver, serving as a sign of the power of divine grace over human weakness.

verses.text: No unbelief made him waver concerning the promise of God, but he grew strong in faith, giving glory to God,
verses.comment: Abraham’s enduring faith is set as a paradigm of trust that glorifies God. His faith is dynamic, growing as a result of God’s faithfulness.

verses.text: being fully convinced that God was able to do what He had promised.
verses.comment: Paul reiterates that faith rests on God’s power and faithfulness, connecting Abraham’s faith to the believer’s trust in the fulfillment of God’s promises.

verses.text: Therefore it was credited to him as righteousness.
verses.comment: The phrase ‘credited as righteousness’ marks the key teaching about justification—God’s declaration rooted in faith, with openness here for considering how faith leads to transformation.

verses.text: But the words 'it was credited to him' were not written for his sake alone,
verses.comment: Paul explains that this teaching applies universally, not to Abraham only, encouraging all believers to see themselves in this saving pattern.

verses.text: but also for ours. It will be credited to us who believe in Him who raised Jesus our Lord from the dead.
verses.comment: Justification continues for all who believe in Christ’s resurrection, the central event vindicating Jesus and establishing His divine authority.

verses.text: He was delivered up for our trespasses and raised for our justification.
verses.comment: Jesus' passion and resurrection fulfill the prophecy of Isaiah 53 and serve as the foundation of Christian faith, uniting believers throughout history in Christ and the grace administered through Him.
